text.p: The following is a direct contribution from commodity statistician F.O. Licht in Ratzeburg, Germany. Please address any queries to Helmut Ahlfeld on +00 49 4541 88920.

White sugar futures in London closed higher helped by firmer physical demand for whites. March added $1.90 to close at $303.30 per tonne, while May ended $1.20 higher at $298.60 per tonne. In New York raw sugar futures closed mixed with front month March adding 6 points to close at 10.45 cents/lb. May added 1 point to close at 10.41 cents/lb, while the outer months lost 1 point. Early gains were not sustained as disappointed speculators liquidated positions and the trade sold near the close. Traders said fund buying in the March/May contracts and trade buying in the spreads gave the market an early boost. However, fundamentals remain negative with no major rally in sight.

RUSSIA - According to official sources sugar beet production in 1996 reached 16.132 million tonnes, up from earlier estimates of 14.9 million tonnes but down on last year's figure of 19.1 million tonnes. The largest producing area, the Central-Chernozem, harvested 7.188 million tonnes of sugar beet in 1996 followed by the North Caucasus area with 4.735 million tonnes and Krasnodar Krai with 3.768 million tonnes.

EUROPEAN UNION - In its estimate of January 29, the EU Commission raised its forecast for beet white sugar production in 1996/97 to 16.168 million tonnes, up from the previous estimate (December 18) of 15.923 million tonnes and last year's production of 15.636 million tonnes. However, even the latest production estimate could be on the low side. In our second estimate of world sugar production 1996/97 we had put EU beet sugar production at 16.384 million tonnes, white value, up from 15.643 million tonnes the previous year. The Commission said that of the total expected to be produced in 1996/97 11.707 million tonnes are likely to be A-quota sugar, 2.435 million tonnes B-quota sugar and 2.988 million tonnes C- sugar. It is expected that the total carried over into 1997/98 will be 900,000 tonnes, so that C-sugar exports are likely to reach 2.088 million tonnes, up from 1.636 million tonnes the previous year. The total sugar available for export (quota and C-sugar) is put at 4.836 million tonnes, up from 4.443 million tonnes the previous year. Given the difficult situation on the Community's export markets it remains to be seen, whether the total quantity can be sold.

ROMANIA - Sugar imports in November 1996 amounted to 68,287 tonnes, raw value, up from last year's 22,673 tonnes. This brought cumulative imports in the first quarter of 1996/97 (September/November) up to 131,776 tonnes compared to 41,390 tonnes in the like period the previous year. Total imports in 1995/96 reached 327,159 tonnes against 275,178 tonnes in 1994/95 and 293,257 tonnes in 1993/94. Major countries of origin in September/November 1996 were Brazil with 81,000 tonnes whites compared to 14,000 tonnes, Austria with 9,165 tonnes compared to 4,241 tonnes and Moldova with 7,683 tonnes against 6,833 tonnes. Sugar exports in September/November 1996 were negligible.

UNITED STATES - Sugar imports in November 1996 amounted to 123,093 tonnes, raw value, up from last year's 86,138 tonnes. This brought cumulative imports in the first two months of 1996/97 (October/November) up to 308,324 tonnes compared to 233,677 tonnes in the like period the previous year. Total imports in 1995/96 amounted to 2.726 million tonnes compared to 1.557 million tonnes in 1994/95 and 1.811 million tonnes in 1993/94. Major countries of origin in October/November 1996 were Peru with 49,750 tonnes raws against 24,539 tonnes, Zimbabwe with 40,785 tonnes against nil, Brazil with 40,253 tonnes against nil and Colombia with 35,106 tonnes compared to 20,155 tonnes. Sugar exports in November 1996 amounted to 22,555 tonnes, raw value, down from last year's 36,478 tonnes. This brought cumulative exports in October/November 1996 up to 43,325 tonnes against 73,652 tonnes in the like period the previous year. Total exports in 1995/96 amounted to 310,341 tonnes against 504,854 tonnes in 1994/95. Major countries of destination in October/November 1996 were Jamaica with 6,956 tonnes whites against 4,555 tonnes and Peru with 6,676 tonnes compared to 6,011 tonnes.

State-owned Taiwan Sugar Corporation passed on a tender for a 30,000 tonne shipment in New York on January 30, a company official said. The shipment was slated for April delivery, it was added. The invitation-only tender was placed on January 30 through Taiwan Sugar's representative office in New York with selected suppliers and was to have been awarded a day later, it was added. Taiwan Sugar will retender the shipment on February 12. The result will be announced the following day in Taipei.
